description.narrative: Juveniles in conflict with the law, children at-risk, child victims/witnesses and children in civil proceedings to be better served and protected by the BiH justice system, including the security and social welfare sectors.

Rättvisa för barn (Justice for children) är en del av UNICEFs treåriga projekt med titeln Skydd av barn i riskzonen och barn som kommer i kontakt med rättsväsendet i Bosnien och Hercegovina. Projektet kommer att stödjas av Sida och den schweiziska styrelsen för internationellt utvecklingssamarbete (SDC). Denna fas inom projektet syftar till att föra det pågående arbetet framåt gällande barnens rätt i Bosnien och Hercegovina (BiH) genom att dra lärdom av redan pågående och implementerade projekt. J4C syftar till att förbättra tillämpningen av internationella normer i Bosnien och Hercegovina när det gäller barnens rätt så att barn blir skyddade och bemötta på rätt sätt av rättssystemet i BiH samt av säkerhetssektorn och sociala välfärdssektorn.

The Justice for Children project (J4C) is a continuation of UNICEF's three-year project entitled Protection of children at-risk and children in contact with the justice system in BiH and will be supported by Swiss Development Cooperation and Sida. This phase will build on the momentum created in advancing justice for children in Bosnia and Herzegovina (BiH), consolidate initiatives underway, and incorporate lessons learned to enhance sustainability of efforts. J4C seeks to improve the application of international standards in BiH so that children are better served and protected by the BiH justice system, including the security and social welfare sectors.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: The project maintained a very good monitoring system with clear baselines and targets. The largest increase over target was in the number of children receiving witness support from specialized support persons in police, prosecutors' offices and courts throughout BiH. The project achieved a 49% reduction of juvenile first time entrants to the justice system from 676 to 334. 142% juveniles were diverted from formal proceedings, well above the 60% target. The target of 200 children annually benefiting from secondary prevention support services has been surpassed significantly and stands at 756 children. Also the targeted 20% increase of juveniles who received alternative measures has been surpassed. Legal aid for children and witness support markers have also been surpassed. The project was gender mainstreamed and included additional trainings on how to identify children at risk, especially boys at risk of offending, and also not to miss subtle signs of risk. All the capacity building activities of the UNICEF project were mainstreamed. A new facility in Orasje for juveniles adopted a new programme with a strong focus on the specific needs of girls in detention. On the sustainability criterion the 2017 evaluation report concluded that the project developed several replicable models and successfully embedded activities into institutional structures. The legislative building component of the project was also deemed to be sustainable with strong update by the relevant ministries. The ministries have been proactively participating in the project coordination board meetings. One of UNICEF strengths is seen in the high quality pool of trained trainers and its collaboration with the various training institutions which ensures that the know how and tools to continue to build the capacity remain after the end of the project.The biggest challenge to effective coordination has come when pursuing state led initiatives. There was much less commitment to coordinating activities across all jurisdictions in these initiatives. Data collection has also proved challenging to the project. Changes have been introduced through HJPC and the Statistical agencies, but there is a need to continually monitor and support these institutions in processing and publishing data on children in the justice system.The floods in the spring of 2014 were a reason for delay of some activities. UNICEF submitted a certified statement of account which show almost all disbursed funds have been spent with a small amount remaining unspent but committed.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
